link.synopsis: White executive Walter Whitney (George Segal) learns unexpectedly that he has a teenage black son, Roger (Denzel Washington). But soon his secret's out, and he loses his job and his wife (Susan Saint James). Forced to start over with nothing, Walter learns firsthand about the challenges facing many minorities.

link.synopsis: Big Brother and the Holding Company played a pivotal role in the 1960s counterculture, when passions ran high, music was afire with originality and one-of-a-kind performers such as the group's headliner, Janis Joplin, burst onto the scene and changed it forever. Discover how the group came to be, watch rarely seen footage and see them in concert serving up hits such as "Ball and Chain," "Blow My Mind" and "Light Is Faster Than Sound."

link.synopsis: A leading composer of the Classical period, Joseph Haydn reshaped the established forms of the string quartet and has been described as the father of the classical symphony. A court musician who was famous in his own time, Haydn earned a name for his majestic masses and choral works, pieces that are still prized repertory standards. This fascinating program, filmed on location in Austria, charts the life and work of the groundbreaking genius.

link.synopsis: A child prodigy, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart performed throughout Europe from the age of 6 and began composing when he was 11. He remains one of the most important and popular composers of European classical music. This illuminating program explores Mozart's life and works, including the obstacles he faced when he tried to establish himself as an independent artist during an age when musicians were seen as servants to the rich and powerful.

link.synopsis: Widely regarded as one of the greatest musical minds of the 19th century, Franz Schubert composed more than 300 sonatas, trios, quartets and quintets; more than 600 romantic lieder; and nine symphonies before his tragic early death at the age of 31. Filmed on location in Schubert's native Austria, this absorbing program explores his life and puts the works of the prolific creative genius in social and historical context.

link.synopsis: While he explored every other avenue of musical composition -- including chamber music, concertos and symphonies -- Johannes Brahms never ventured into opera. Part of a comprehensive series of films celebrating the most influential composers of all time, this educational program reviews the progression of his works and analyzes his creative genius.

link.synopsis: Famous action star Rick Stone (Danny Fendley) is going through a nasty divorce court with wife Michelle (Brigitte Nielsen) when sneaky TV tabloid reporter Dana Fields (Dana Plato) acquires an intimate video of Stone and his lover. Fields airs the footage, which helps Michelle in the divorce proceedings. But alimony payment is the least of Stone's problems when Michelle is found dead. Stone, the prime suspect, asks Fields to help clear his name.

link.synopsis: Based on the best-selling book by Pulitzer Prize-winner Daniel Yergin and Joseph Stanislaw, this three-part PBS documentary series confronts head-on critical concerns about the new interconnected world. The three segments -- "The Battle of Ideas," "The Agony of Reform" and "The New Rules of the Game" -- begin with the dawn of technological change in 1914, taking an in-depth look at globalization and how it will affect our society's future.

link.synopsis: "Clutch Cargo" was one of the most popular children's shows of the 1950s and pioneered the use of Synchro-vox technology (animation that superimposed real human lips over the mouths of cartoon drawings). The series, created by cartoonist Clark Haas, followed the globetrotting adventures of the titular pilot, his child companion, Spinner, and a dog named Paddlefoot. This video includes the first 26 episodes of the series' 52-episode run.

link.synopsis: Based on Clifton L. Taulbert's autobiography, Tim Reid's heartfelt directorial debut profiles an African American boy coming of age in the segregated South. Growing up in Mississippi, Cliff witnesses Ku Klux Klan marches and experiences discrimination. With the help of his uncle (Richard Roundtree) and great-grandfather (Al Freeman Jr.), he becomes an honors student and helps his community stand up to racism.

link.synopsis: Discover the life and music of Antonin Dvorak, among the greatest Czech composers, in this unique biography. Dvorak's music provides a soundtrack for lyrical dance segments filmed in the Bohemian countryside where he lived and worked. Historical insights by classical music authorities reveal the composer's intense nationalism, evident in the abundance of traditional folk melodies woven into many of his masterpieces.

link.synopsis: British rockers Coldplay burst onto the scene in 1996, and by the dawn of the new millennium had claimed their first international hit with the single "Yellow." This documentary chronicles that journey. Charting a remarkable evolution, the film tells the band's story, from their University College London beginnings to their present-day superstar status. None of the band's music is included.

link.synopsis: Grammy Award-winning band Coldplay and their meteoric rise to fame are the subject of this unauthorized documentary. Through rarely seen footage, photos and interviews with band members and their friends and colleagues, this biography charts the group's history, chronicling their beginning from a chance meeting in college, exploring their influences and style, and tracing their rapid ascent to becoming one of the most successful UK bands ever.
